headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: Abu Dhabi Planning Record-Setting Fireworks Spectacle; World's First Arab Pitmaster Speaks to CNN; Athens Counts Down to 2025. Aired 2-3p ET

utterances.speaker: BECKY ANDERSON, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, you're watching CNN's special coverage of New Year's Eve across the globe. I'm Becky Anderson in Dubai where the New Year is just an hour away. It is already 2025, of course in much of Asia. And CNN has taken you from the fireworks in Sydney harbor and will be with you all the way to the ball dropping in New York.And Abu Dhabi has a record setting firework plan. They've been launching fireworks every hour leading up to midnight. That is all part of an attempt to set six Guinness World records during the celebrations at the Sheikh Zayed Festival about 45 minutes from where we are here in Dubai. And then in less than an hour when midnight strikes, there will be an hour long presentation of fireworks in the Abu Dhabi Al Wathba desert. You will not want to miss that. Well, back, -- well, back to Dubai where the excitement is also building towards the start of the New Year at the top of the hour. Here joining us now, Malaysian entrepreneur, motivational speaker and businessman Vishen Lakhiani, the CEO, founder, mind behind Mindvalley, which is a global. It's about personal power empire, I mean, it's all about the work that he does, is all about self-improvement. And is co- host of the podcast, the Mindvalley podcast is with us as well, that's Megan Pormer and entrepreneur Sara Al Madani. Thank you all for being here. It's been good to have you for the past hour. You're with me through the next hour or so. You've interviewed, Vishen, so many self-help experts. What are the biggest takeaways that you have got from those discussions?

utterances.speaker: VISHEN LAKHIANI, CEO, MINDVALLEY
utterances.sentences: So many ideas but I think one of the biggest takeaways is you got to live life on your own terms, right? So many of us feel trapped by the lifestyles and the ideas of our parents, our society. But there's a meme on the internet I love and I think it says this, tradition that you don't like is nothing more than peer pressure from dead people.Sarah embodies this. You got to question the things that don't fit you. People who tell you, oh, you can't do that. They're simply saying, look at me, my chains are bigger.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: There'll be people listening to you who -- they'll be really -- they'll be inspired by what you're saying, but they'll say, listen, it's a tough old world out there. It's chaotic, it's -- it's busy, it's distracting. I just can't find my space, I can't find my own voice. And you'll hear that all the time. It's the reason that many people use your platforms, of course. How do we find our voice in 2025?

utterances.speaker: MEGAN PORMER, HOST, MINDVALLEY PODCAST
utterances.sentences: Look for a microphone. And by microphone, I mean, look for the closest platform around you, which right now everybody has social media at their disposal. Everybody can have a social media profile and speak their mind. Find your microphone and speak your mind. There is nothing that can stop you right now.You know, back like 20 years ago, all of us had the excuse of oh, you know, there's no microphone, I don't have the freedom to speak my voice. But right now, social media has given that excuse away from us.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Yeah, you're right. I mean everybody has a platform. Sorry, you use that platform a lot, what is that one piece of advice that you are going to be throwing onto your social channels and saying, guys, get with the program. Here it is. This is what you need to do in 2025.

utterances.speaker: SARA AL MADANI, ENTREPRENEUR
utterances.sentences: I mean, look, I was blessed with a platform and I feel like I'm responsible of everything I put on my platform, my social media. And if I'm not giving something worthy, then I'm not worthy of being followed. So I have to add value. And if you want to see the world better, you got to be better. You said, how do I find my voice? It's by disconnecting and going within finding your voice and just taking it out there and be authentic.And us, especially women, we come from generations and generations of silence women. So this throat chakra is open and we're not going to be quiet anymore. I want women to speak up, I want men to speak up, you know, and just speak your truth.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: In this hyper connected world, you talk to so many people who are so lonely --

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: -- so lonely. What do we do about that? What do they do about that?

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: Oh my God. Yes.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Well, (inaudible) been invited. You and I have known each other --

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: We're going to start. We are going to start, Becky.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: You've been invited by (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: Yes --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: You've been invited, Sara? Excellent (inaudible). I'm in. January. Let me know when --

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: Done.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Listen, as we move out of 2024, around this region it's been a lot of conflict and a lot of pain. I know so many of us here in this region and around the world are looking for a bit of stability, a bit of peace, I mean, just a sense that we can stand as you and I talked about earlier on shoulder to shoulder, at this point. I mean, for those out there, it's not about making New Year's resolutions, is it? It's about standing shoulder to shoulder.

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: It's about finding resolution with one another. It's about understanding that we're all lonely, we're all in conflict within ourselves. We're all in pain. Why don't we just hold hands, regardless of our gender, our religion and our culture and really help each other get through the earth school (ph)?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: I'm listening to the tunes behind me. I love this. I love this. I love it. What was your song of 2024?

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: My song of 2024? I think it's by Teddy Swim. It's called Lose Control.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Love it.

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: I love it. It's nice.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Love it. Love it. Taylor Swift or Sabrina Carpenter.

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: Sabrina Carpenter. Because she said, heartbreak is one thing, my ego's another.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to ask you that because I'm not sure you know who Sabrina Carpenter is. Do you?

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: No. I'm a Carla Bruni fan. Yeah, I'm all about Carla Bruni.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: All right, let me ask you this. What's the best movie you saw in 2024?

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: That's so easy. Deadpool and Wolverine. So good. Ryan Reynolds is a genius.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Best series, best TV series -- LAKHIANI

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: That was a classic.

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Becky, you don't want to know, because I love horror. My favorite genre is horror movies.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: I can't hear you. So I'm just --

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Oh, I said my favorite genre -- my favorite genre is horror movies.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness gracious. That is -- I'm dropping horror movies in 2024. My favorite series this year, Rivals. Absolutely loved it. Did you see that?

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: For me, it's The Notebook over and over again --

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Oh my God, I love The Notebook.

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: -- because I need that unity.

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: I love The Notebook.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: All right, well, listen, guys, stay with me. We've been cooking up more than just fireworks for you here to ring in the New Year in Dubai. Hattem Mattar, restaurant owner and the world's first Arab pitmaster, is working his magic. And let me tell you, you can't even put these amazing smells into words. Hattem is with us. Can you hear me, Hattem? How's the grilling going over there?HATTEM MATTAR, WORLD'S FIRST ARAB PITMASTER: Okay, so tomahawks are almost done. As you can clearly see, we've spiced them. We've got this wonderful camel stock I'm going to show you, right? We're going to take this camel stock that we've been making over the same oak fire, right? Watch your camera. Okay and we've got a brush that we're using that consists of rosemary, mint, parsley, coriander, and we use that to glaze the tomahawks, right? Calms down the fire a bit. Look at that cherry color. And basically, because the oak fire is turned into charcoal, you're going to get all of that oak flavor in the tomahawk. We're going to slice that tomahawk over the mandi rice. Take that mandi rice with the tomahawk in one bite. And if you're brave, you can actually eat with your hands.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Wow. Listen, I'm just going to say --

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Yeah --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Doesn't matter. (Inaudible)

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: My mouth is watering watching this.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: We're all going to get to experience this a little later. In just under three hours, one of the world's oldest cities will be saying hello to 2025. My colleague Eleni Giokos is in Athens with a look at the festivities there.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Well, in a couple of hours from now, in one of the oldest cities in the world, they will be bringing in the New Year. We're of course here in Dubai, but the sky above Athens, Greece will be lit up with fireworks to welcome in 2025. And that's where we find my colleagues, Eleni Giokos. Eleni, what is the mood like there in Athens?

utterances.speaker: ELENI GIOKOS, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It is incredible. Look, I'm at one of the biggest parties happening in this city and of course it's going to kick off in around an hour's time. You've got music, you've got DJs, and if anyone knows Greece, it's all about partying until the sun comes up.But I have to say, and this is -- I guess the rest of the world gets gifts on Christmas Eve, but Greeks do it differently. And we have someone called Agios Vasileios, St. Basil. And Becky, I have to say I took the liberty of writing to him on behalf of you so you can experience some of the Greek magic. And I believe he dropped off a gift. And I think your team has something ready.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Hello.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: And please, once you open it, tell me what it is.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) as if by magic. As if by magic, I get a gift from Eleni. Here we go. Well, it's beautifully wrapped.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Well, it's St. Basil.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Hold on, let me put this down.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Okay, tell me what it is

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Eleni, you wrapped it up so well I can't open it.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: It was Agios Vasileios, it wasn't me. He clearly likes to make sure that things are, you know, difficult to open.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Okay. Eleni, I'm getting --

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: So this is a really important -- it's a really important ritual, right? It's something really important for us. Everyone opens gifts on New Year's Eve for the New Year. And tell me what you got?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: It's an owl.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: And I think it's something --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: That is beautiful.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: It's an owl. Okay --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Tell me.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Sitting on my shoulder.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: -- on New Year's Eve is we have this -- Good. That's why you should carry it. We have something called the vasilopita. This is absolutely magical. Inside there is a coin, and we cut it up and whoever gets the piece with the coin has the best luck in the year.Now, the team in Abu Dhabi will know that I baked a few of these. And we've done this in Abu Dhabi for the UAE team. So this is something else that Greeks do. It's very much part of our culture as well as religion. And frankly, it brings in sort of positive vibes for the New Year. And the other thing is, and I have to say, this is a message to the entire world, whatever you do on New Year's Day sets the tone for the rest of the year and Greeks fundamentally believe this. So be careful how you feel and what you do, because you'll probably be doing it for the rest of 2025. So what are your plans, Becky, for (inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Well, I hope -- my plans are to get up early with the kids then and not to have a hangover, because I don't want to go into 2025 with a hangover ever.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Oh, there you go. That's a good plan.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: It's never a good -- never a good idea. I'll get up early with the kids and I'll, you know, I'll go into 2025 like that. Thank you. Behind you some ice skating --

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: -- people are enjoying themselves there. When did they set that up? Is it cold?

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Well, they wanted me -- they wanted me to do some ice skating, but I would fall over and embarrass myself on CNN, so decided not to. But there's ice skating. This is actually the Stavros Niarchos Cultural Center. There's always an ice skate rink here, which is fantastic.And we're going to have music. There's going to be incredible DJs and other performances as well. People are going to start arriving. 20,000 people came to this location last year for New Year's Eve celebrations. They're expecting a lot more this year. We're going to have fireworks. It's going to be a big party. And as you can see, it's a very -- it's a very big family affair. And Greeks have come out to enjoy themselves and bring in the New Year with the bang. And then there will also be very first run of the year. So 12 a.m. so as we get in the New Year -- I think 1, 300 people have signed up to run 3km. So that's a good way to bring in the New Year, you know, nice and healthy and with positive vibes. I won't be doing that, though. I'm going to chill.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: I was going to -- I was going to ask you, you going to be doing that? Well, for those who are, good luck to them.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Nope, nope.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Fantastic. I know there's traditional dancing that goes alongside some of these traditions --

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: -- that you have in Greece. Are you expecting to see some of that tonight where you are?

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Yes, we're going to have dancing. There's going to be some incredible things. We also got, you know, lots of carols that people -- I was experiencing this in Athens today. I just went to the store and then I had these kids. Everyone was singing what we call calanda. And then you pay these kids, you know, one or two euros and everyone comes out on the street.And I remember when my parents used to make me do this in South Africa as an immigrant child I was always so embarrassed. But I see people here doing it with such love and I mean, honestly, just enjoying it and not feeling embarrassed. I've now got a different perspective of being Greek and then singing these carols all over the place in public. And it's -- it's amazing, you know --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Wonderful.

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: -- as a foreigner, because I feel like a foreigner here a lot of the time. Seeing it in person and experiencing the true Greek New Year's Eve, I'm telling you, Becky, it's amazing. I'm so lucky to be here.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Wonderful. Well, we're lucky to have you there. And thank you from you --

utterances.speaker: GIOKOS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: -- and from Greece. I'm going to keep this in the office to keep me company going into 2025 and beyond. Thank you. Eleni Giokos is in Athens.For the busy football calendar, creating stress and potential injuries for many of its stars. CNN's Amanda Davies was in Dubai this week and she spoke to one of Real Madrid's players about what he thinks should be done. Let's do a little bit of soccer for you before we take a very short break. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: AMANDA DAVIES, CNN WORLD SPORT
utterances.sentences: You have been very vocal in terms of your criticism playing too many games. What is your solution? What do you want to see happen?

utterances.speaker: DAVIES
utterances.sentences: Do you think anybody is actually listening to the players?

utterances.speaker: COURTOIS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: DAVIES
utterances.sentences: So do you think it will change?

utterances.speaker: COURTOIS
utterances.sentences: Not at the moment. I think I'm sure like the FIFPRO they're trying to protect the players, definitely. But they obviously association for the players. But I think other government bodies, they don't think about it because -- obviously this new Club World Cup I think is exciting to play. I think it's something that has to exist, but it's just so hard to find the right way into it. I think clubs want to help, but we all follow the rules and follow the calendar we get given, you know.(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: And this is Expo City in Dubai. People really beginning to move around, dancing under the Al Wasl Dome and getting ready for the fireworks here and around the UAE some 40 or so minutes from now.I also want to get you to Kenya's capital of Nairobi where the clock will strike midnight in less than two hours. A collective cheer will then fill the air as fireworks light up the night sky there. While it is a festive season, authorities say the use of fireworks that only happen at authorized venues from midnight to 12:30 a.m. local time. Well, CNN'S Victoria Rubadiri will be watching those celebrations unfold. And she joins us now live from Nairobi. What's the mood like there in the city, Victoria?

utterances.speaker: VICTORIA RUBADIRI, CNN
utterances.sentences: All right. Becky --

utterances.speaker: JULIA VARGAS JONES, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hello.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Superstition aside, Rio holds the most famous New Year's party in Brazil. Just describe the scene.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, it does and -- oh, okay. We got some water here, Becky. Sorry about that. Look, the reason why I am so close to the water right now is because I'm about to do something that most Brazilians will do at one point or another on New Year's Eve, which is to give flowers to the goddess of the sea. Can you come with me? I'm trying to convince my cameraman to get a little wet as well.(Speaking foreign language). This girl's going to help me. You're going to show me (speaking foreign language) how it's done. (Speaking foreign language). One, dois, tres. Good job. (Inaudible) What's your name? (Speaking foreign language). WOMAN #1: (Inaudible)

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible). Thank you so much for your help. Happy New Year. Feliz ano novo. This is what this is all about, Becky. This kind of tradition, deep, deep rooted tradition in African religions, actually, that has transpired and has built up Brazilian culture. You know, we were talking the last hour, why is it that we get into these culture crowded spaces to celebrate New Year's? This is what it's about. It's about finding the things that draw us together, right.To spend shoulder to shoulder in this beautiful place, but sharing this culture, this important moment as we say goodbye to 2024 -- oh, my God. Thank you so much. (Speaking foreign language). (Speaking foreign language). Do you want to throw it back again? Okay. I'm not sure she's quite well versed in the tradition yet, but we'll -- we'll get her there. Becky.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: I love it. And Julia's wearing white, which is really important there in Brazil.As I am here with our -- our friends here at the Expo in Dubai. You guys have been moving around a little bit. You're (inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: I know the vibe is just so (inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: What do you think of the music tonight?

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: It's just so amazing here --

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: The music is so good.

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: -- the energy, people. Everyone's so happy. I'm feeling it in my bones.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: We're going to see -- you're going to meet DJ Brooklyn in a minute. He's not bad.

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: He's really good.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: He's really good.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: It's really good to see people moving around. And, you know, this is -- this is such a family affair. You've all bought your families with you tonight, haven't you?

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: You know, Becky, I flew in my mother from Los Angeles. He flew with his family. She's here with her son. And here it feels like a big family. We're all a big soul family. And it's time for all of us to recognize that we're all one. And we're here to celebrate this oneness. This year, it's all about you love me and I love you. And you forgive me, and I forgive you.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: All right. Welcome back. This is New Year's Eve waiting to ring in the New Year here in Dubai at Expo City with our friends here, Sara Al Madani, Vishen and Megan. Sara's actually just brought her son. And who's this? What's your name? Hey.

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Maktum (ph), say hi MAN #1

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Hi, Maktum (ph). You looking forward to 2025?

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Yes, we're looking forward.MAN #1: Definitely.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: How was the festive season?MAN #1: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, good for you, Maktum (ph). These are both Dubai residents. Maktum (ph), I think, grew up in Dubai. These two are in and out of Dubai. Wow. It's going to be a fantastic New Year.Amanda Davies, my colleague, has been in Dubai this past week hooking up with a number of footballers. United fans, Man United fans are going to be hoping that the New Year brings an upturn in fortunes after a pretty dismal 2024. That football club, of course, language is in the bottom half of the English Premier League with problems on and off the pitch. So Amanda talked with the former United legend Rio Ferdinand while she was here in Dubai about how the club might turn things around. Have a look at this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DAVIES
utterances.sentences: What is a realistic target for this season in your opinion? I mean --

utterances.speaker: RIO FERDINAND, FORMER DEFENDER, MANCHESTER UNITED
utterances.sentences: I don't think -- it's weird to say this at Manchester United, but I just don't think we can put targets on things. We're not in a position to do that. We have a lot of rebuilding, not of players individually, of a team, but also of a culture and environment.There are four big components that need to be rebuilt and that's going to take time. So to put then a target above that in terms of position and winning things is just I think that takes away from all of those four things that need building.

utterances.speaker: DAVIES
utterances.sentences: Do you think there's anything that can be learned from Liverpool when you look at, you know, how smoothly that transition has gone since Jurgen Klopp's departure, which could have gone very horribly wrong the other way, couldn't it?

utterances.speaker: FERDINAND
utterances.sentences: I think it's a whole different ball game and the way Liverpool have had that transitional period compared to Man United. It is a lot of confusion and noise over this side compared to very seamless, quiet kind of approach.But also don't forget that their squad was a much more stable squad as well. Let's say people who have won at that club have been there for a long time, so they had the components in there that were working, just wasn't maybe working the right way and needed fine tuning.

utterances.speaker: DAVIES
utterances.sentences: Do you see them as favorites for the Premier League?

utterances.speaker: FERDINAND
utterances.sentences: I do now, yeah. I didn't before (inaudible) was kicked this season. I thought (inaudible) would win it again. Arsenal would run them close, but I think Liverpool have come out of traps fast. They've got a consistency that no one seems to be matching at the moment, so they're the team to beat.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: All right. You join me away from the CNN set here at Expo City because we've been promising you over this past, what, 90 minutes or so, an absolute culinary delight from the Arab world's first Pitmaster, Mr. Hattem Mattar. We've been following your progress, sir, over the last, like 90 minutes or so. How are you getting on?

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: We're -- we're done. We're done. And I don't mean well done, pun intended. Tomahawks are done. Cooked to 145Fahrenheit. I don't know what that means to my American friends. I don't know what that is in Celsius, but here we go.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Sit down. Show builds my cameraman, get down and have a look at this.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: So we smoked this over oak, Texas oak to be exact. And if you -- can you see the color on this? ANDERSON

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Is that fantastic?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Looks amazing.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: So we're going to dress this over the mandi rice that we made with tomato dakkous. We've got a sticky date barbecue sauce for the ribs. And if you're brave. Are you going to eat with your hands with me?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. I'm going to eat with my hands. And this is where the Arabic fusion comes in. The rice, the sticky date. Tell me about the rice. Tell our viewers around the world who may not be as familiar with this as you are.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: We talked earlier on about how barbecuing is often seen as a sort of western, of times U.S. I mean, you know, Texas, southern states, barbecuing is like -- it's the heart and soul of the cooking. But here, you know, here around this region, food is about getting together. It's about community. It's about communal experience. And that's what barbecuing is all about

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: 100%. Food and the invitation to your house is part of Arab hospitality. In Arabic, we say, (speaking foreign language), which is essentially your neighbor's house before yours. And that's how we treat every meal. If you finish your plate, you'll be served more whether you want to or not, right? Once, twice, three times. And there's no barbecue -- there's no cuisine that does that like barbecue. And there's no way to do it better than to put barbecue over one of our national dishes.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Look at this. What's he putting on here now?

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: So we've got raisins, we've got a mix of nuts. We're going to cover it in parsley. We're going to slice the meat over top, and this is enough for me, you and the crew and maybe half of expo.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Well, we're going to offer it to everybody who's here, of course. Let's just introduce me to your helper here tonight.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Dhanmia (ph) is our pitmaster. He's from Bangladesh, learned from scratch, and he's my eyes and ears and my pitmaster when I'm away, he knows everything I know, and I'm super honored that he's part of our team. We've kind of passed the torch to him.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Amazing. Amazing. You enjoying yourself tonight?MAN #2: Yes, ma'am. (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: What's the green that you put? This is parsley, is it?

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Parsley, correct.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Amazing. And these are raisins I can see here --

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Two kinds of raisins --

utterances.speaker: ANDRSON
utterances.sentences: Yeah. These are cashew nuts.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Wow. Guys, it looks absolutely amazing. You talked about the sticky dates earlier. Tell me about that.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: The sticky dates -- the sticky date dressing is over these ribs.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Okay? Are you giving us any secrets here? I mean, you're telling us, yeah, there's some sticky date dressing over these ribs, but people are going to be yeah, but what's in his ingredient? What's his super, super secret ingredient?

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: The secret ingredient to barbecue is don't get your wood wrong. If you get your wood wrong, you can't cover that with barbecue sauce. And, I don't know if I should say this, asking for barbecue sauce at a barbecue restaurant is like asking for ketchup at a pizza restaurant. ANDERSONof restaurants asking for tomato ketchup.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Now the dates, the cinnamon. We've got cardamom in there, we've got bay leaf. Traditional ingredients that we use for our dishes. But in a barbecue sauce that you would expect on any Texas dinner table.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: How good does this look? I've promised our guests tonight and our friends over there by the DJ booth who will be seeing some moments from now that they'll get to experience this with us. And for all of you, wherever you are watching around the world, I'm sorry that you don't actually get to experience this with us, but you'll have a virtual experience. It's almost as good, right?

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Close, close, close.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Are you still cooking in the garden? You used to cook in your garden in Dubai. That's how you -- because you were an engineer, right?

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: If you can believe it, when we first started, we did a piece with CNN called Feast on Dubai. We were with Michelin star chefs at the time it was Vineet Bhatia and two Gordon Ramsay trained chefs. And I was like the new kid on the block. When CNN called, I was like, are you guys sure you have the right number? And 10 years later, now we're the number one pop up in the country.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: It's amazing. Can't wait to celebrate with you at the fireworks in about 20 minutes time.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible)I'll see you across -- these are the fireworks. Oh, my goodness, look at these. Looks absolutely amazing. We are going to take a very short break, but stay with us folks here at Expo City. We've got an awesome awful lot more to come. We want some -- 20 minutes or so is about -- is it about 20 to the hour at this point? Somebody tell me, 20 minutes? 20 minutes to go. 20 minutes to go until the top of the hour. I will be joined by Laura Coates and Boris Sanchez, my colleagues in Paris and in London today. Stay with us, folks. Back after this. WOMAN #2: New Zealand's are in the future. They're among the first in the world to celebrate the arrival of 2025.

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: The New Year is almost here. While it's still 2024 in the United States. All across the globe, revelers are winging in 2025.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Together, we are doing what only CNN can do, taking you live from time zone to time zone to multiple countries with their own cultures, traditions and fabulous New Year celebrations.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Wherever you are around the world, throw on your finery (ph) or at least your finest headgear and celebrate alongside some of the world's most iconic musicians.MAN #4: My wish for 2025 is peace and love.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Celebrity chefs, international superstars, and us, we're making it up as we go.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: With appearances from Sting, Morgan Freeman, Shania Twain.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Al Green, Colin Hay of Men at Work, Adam Devine, Sixpence None the Richer, and the Notre-Dame Choir.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: This is a CNN special event.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: New Year's Eve, live.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Welcome everyone in the United States and all around the world. You are in for an awesome show. I'm Laura Coates in London. Cheers from right in front of the London Eye.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And I'm Boris Sanchez, right on the famous Champs Elysees in Paris and the Arc de Triomphe behind me is lit up like you've never seen it before. We are about to experience a spectacle of sight and sound and light and music with about a million of our closest friends. Something unlike what you will see anywhere else.Laura, I got to be honest with you, I almost didn't make it tonight. I was ill all of yesterday and today. I had a fever, a horrible cough, there was phlegm everywhere. I was fortunate to get a telemedicine appointment with this French doctor, the most French experience you could imagine. He was vaping during the appointment and he asked that in exchange for prescribing me essentially an entire pharmacy worth of drugs. I give him a shout out on the air. So, Dr. Ellie Benahum (ph), wherever you are, sir, happy New Year to you. If you hear me get loopy and what I say doesn't make any sense, I promise you, Laura, I've had not a bit of alcohol tonight. It's purely the meds.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Sure, Boris, purely the meds. I understand. Wink, wink. I'm glad you're with us today --

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: I promise.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: -- and my God, I'm so glad --

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: No, I promise.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: -- you're able to make it. And for everyone out there, first of all, anyone wonder why I'm the one in London and I have the beret on and Boris does not? I'm just saying, I'm not going to throw shade, but it does look pretty good. I mean, what do you guys think? Here we are in front of this magical place, the London Eye is behind me.I did not intentionally coordinate. I intentionally coordinated. I called London. I was like, listen, I'm wearing (inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You definitely intentionally coordinated.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. Listen, it's behind me. It's a magical time -- I did. I really did. You know, I did. Listen, Boris, coming up minutes from now, you've got midnight in Dubai. You've got midnight in Abu Dhabi. And if history tells us anything, Boris, Dubai is going to be spectacular.I'm talking about the city that once launched half a million fireworks in a single display, mind you. From the city's top landmarks, including the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa, turning the Arabian night into a kaleidoscope of color that could probably be seen from space. We've got CNN's Becky Anderson, who is live from Dubai at the DJ booth. Becky, are you going to spin for us?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Do what you did just earlier on with me because you said, watch this. You know, I asked him earlier on, have you got your favorite tune? And obviously every DJ has its -- has his favorite tune, which is the tune that gets people going and show them what you did to me earlier on when you actually suddenly got this crowd move.MAN #5: I did. And while you were walking away I played Michael Jackson and you saw the reaction, so it worked.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: It's Michael Jackson. He tells me that is the song that gets everybody going wherever he DJs, anywhere in the world. Not necessarily your favorite, right? But it gets the crowds moving.MAN #5: Always, Always. Any -- any song. Any song. As long as you're not playing any slow song for sure. It's like any -- any Michael Jackson party song gets the people on.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: How long have you been DJing?MAN #5: 18 years now.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Right. Okay. So you've got enormous amount of music up there in your head. (Inaudible). And let me tell you this, you will know what to do next.MAN #5: I have a hard drive built in right here with -- with all the music. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: You will know what to do next. Because, Laura, as I understand it, Laura, you're into a bit of R&B? I think I'm right (inaudible).And then Boris (inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: R&B, all of it.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible). So he's one of those bad boys -- I am hearing you. Yes.MAN #5: I'll play a song for both of them.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Okay.MAN #5: It goes both ways because --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Okay.MAN #5: I'll -- I'll do it. I'll do it in one go. ANDERSON: Okay. He's going to do it in one go. This is for you guys.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Okay.MAN #5: Can you guys hear that?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Yeah.MAN #5: Cn they hear that?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Can you hear that? Did you hear it?MAN #5: That's for Laura and --

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I want to hear it. I hear it. Hold on. It's making me move.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: From Miami.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I hear it --MAN #5: Boris from Miami. Laura, shout out to you, guys.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I love it.MAN #5: Thank you guys for coming in. I'm having fun --

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: It covers.MAN #5: I'll see you --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Masterclass. Before that, you show me what you dMAN #5: (Inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: -- to get these guys moving tonight. I know I said to you, I'm going to get a masterclass. He's like, I don't think you're going to be any good at this. All right, quickly, show me.MAN #5: Let's do it this way. Okay.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: YeahMAN #5: You ready?

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Nice. Love it. Happy New Year. Thank you.All right, so we are underneath the Al Wasl Dome here, 70 meters high at 242 projectors on what is the world's largest immersive experience. This is effectively a huge projector. Give it time, Dubai. Look at these crowds gathered here. What I'm doing for you guys is taking you up through the crowds. We're just about 10 or less minutes away from New Year's Eve at this point. This is Dubai. Look at all these faces. Look at the happiness that we see here. What we're doing is we are taking you to a very special party that's going on over here with a very special man because Laura and Boris, I've got here the Arab world's first ever Pitmaster. Now, I know that you guys are Americans, and I know that you think that Americans do barbecue better than anybody else, but that is not true, or at least not necessarily true here in Dubai. As I go through, let me introduce you both to Hattem Mattar and my friends this evening, Megan, the family. Hi, guys. Look at this. Come on in, Charbel (ph), and have a look at this.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: You asked, we delivered.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Tell Laura and Boris and everybody watching around the world what we have here.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: So this is an oak smoked tomahawk mandi with sticky smoked ribs and a pure harvest tomato dakkous. That's it. That's what -- that's a mouthful.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Where did you learn to cook like this? Hattem. Engineer from Egypt.

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: Emirati. Sorry. Egyptian born, Emirati raised, Texas trains in my backyard and in Bastrop, Texas. Shout out to Southside Market and Brian Bracewell (ph).

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: 100%. Barbecue culture belongs everywhere in the UAE this is called -- if you cook this underground, it would be called tanoor, which is essentially the Arabic word for underground barbecue. In Jordan they call it zarb. In Oman, they call it shuwa. So barbecue culture is a huge part of Arab culture and we just added a Texas twist to it.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Hey. Well, we are getting ready to welcome in 2025. Sarah Al Madani is with me. Megan is with me as well. Megan is from the -- she's the co-host of the Mindvalley podcast. All about self- improvement, mind body wellness and all of that good stuff. What's your advice to our viewers for 2025, Megan?

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: My advice is that let go of any limiting belief that no longer serve you. Do not believe your limiting belief. This year is about having it all.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: It's about having it all, Laura and Boris. Poor Boris hasn't been very well. I hope you get a better start to 2025 than you have had health wise in the back end of 2024, mate. What are your goals for 2025, sweetheart?

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: More boundaries, more self-love, more observing, not absorbing. Reciprocation -- 2025 is reciprocation. If you can't give me something, I can't give it to you.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Real Housewives of Dubai. Season two is just finished, we think there will be a season three and when there is a season three, you will see Sarah Al Madani once again hitting your big screens with housewives. What are you looking forward to most in 2025?

utterances.speaker: MATTAR
utterances.sentences: I'm looking forward to opening our first branch internationally. I'm looking forward to coming back to the States to do more culinary diplomacy. I'm looking forward to you finding this on all of the airlines, all of the hospitality outlets, all of the hotels in the UAE and abroad and for (inaudible) to be household in.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Nice. And what are we leaving behind in 2024? This is Vishen Lakhiani who's from Mindvalley. He's the founder, the CEO of this enormous global empire that is Mindvalley these days. What are you leaving behind in 2024?

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: I can't hear a thing.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: What are you leaving behind?

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: I'm leaving behind a whole slew of bad decisions this year.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: You going to share any of those decisions with us?

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: Not on CNN, no. My Mistakes are my private matter.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: All right, we are getting ready. We got two minutes to go. Two minutes to go. London and Paris before the fireworks. Here, let me just explain what we're going to do here, because we're at Expo City. This is where the Expo was held back in 2021. And this Al Wasl Dome is the sort of centerpiece of what is this remarkable new part of Dubai.So you're going to see the fireworks here. You're also going to see the fireworks at the Burj Khalifa. And they will be impressive, let me tell you. They always are. Always absolutely fantastic. But as I said a little bit earlier on, you also are going to get to experience the desert in Abu Dhabi this year, Al Wathba, where the Sheikh Zayed Festival is being held. And they are hoping to break a whole load of records tonight with fireworks and leisure shows and drone shows. So we're going to see those. You'll see them on your screens just, what, 90 seconds or so from now. This is going to be us ringing in. And what you'll see around this dome here, just moments from now is the countdown clock. And that countdown clock will begin at about 30 seconds to go. And you'll hear the countdown happening in languages from all over the world. Look, there's more than 200 nationalities here in Dubai. And that will be reflected at least in part tonight by a countdown in multiple languages. We'll get to 10. That'll be in English. And that is where I know you will hear this crowd go absolutely wild. In fact, I think they're beginning. You can feel it coming. Feel it coming, guys. They're getting the projections ready to go. As we leave 24 behind you. Say goodbye. Good riddance. Oh, that wasn't bad, but it's going to be better in 25.

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: Personal challenges, professional success. Goodbye, 2024. That's it. That's enough.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: Excellent. Goodbye to 24.

utterances.speaker: MADANI
utterances.sentences: Goodbye to 24.

utterances.speaker: PORMER
utterances.sentences: Welcome, 2025.

utterances.speaker: LAKHIANI
utterances.sentences: Welcome, 2025.
